title: Arco Nano vs Arco Primo
comparison_headline: How small can you go without giving up real espresso?
comparison_intro: The Nano is the smallest electric espresso machine we make — designed to disappear into a kitchen and still deliver a proper shot. The Primo is compact by any standard, but gives you a full-sized portafilter and a workflow closer to what you would find in a cafe. The trade-off is counter space.
hero_image_alt: Arco Nano and Arco Primo espresso machines on a narrow kitchen counter next to a toaster and kettle, the Nano dramatically smaller, both in matte black, a tape measure subtly visible to emphasise size difference, bright morning kitchen light

pressure_control.product_a: 15 bar pump (9 bar at group), fixed
pressure_control.product_b: 15 bar pump (9 bar at group), fixed OPV

steam_capability.product_a: Panarello-style steam wand — adequate for basic frothing, not for latte art
steam_capability.product_b: Single boiler steam — must switch modes, but produces drier steam with more control

grind_compatibility.product_a: Works with any grinder; 54 mm portafilter is less sensitive to dose variation
grind_compatibility.product_b: 58 mm commercial portafilter — compatible with aftermarket baskets as your skills develop

suitable_for.product_a: Tiny kitchens, secondary brewing stations, and anyone who values a minimal footprint above all else
suitable_for.product_b: People who want a proper 58 mm portafilter workflow and a more capable steam system in a still-compact package

not_suitable_for.product_a: Anyone serious about milk texturing or latte art — the Panarello wand gets you foam, not microfoam
not_suitable_for.product_b: People with genuinely limited counter space — the Primo is compact but still needs a dedicated spot

morning-minimalist.rationale: If your morning ritual is one black espresso with no fuss, the Nano's 45-second heat-up and tiny footprint make it nearly invisible in your routine.

upgrader.rationale: The 58 mm portafilter gives you a path to better baskets and accessories as you learn — the Nano's 54 mm limits your upgrade options.

traveller.rationale: While neither is truly portable, the Nano is light enough to move between rooms or bring to a holiday rental.

non-barista.rationale: Fewer variables and faster heat-up — the Nano is the closest thing to push-button espresso in our manual range.

verdict: The Nano is a genuinely good espresso machine that happens to be very small. It does not taste like a compromise unless you are chasing latte art or want to grow into competition baskets. The Primo costs a little more and takes a little more space, but its 58 mm portafilter and better steaming make it the stronger foundation if you think your interest in espresso might deepen over time.
